abstract: Better-than-expected earnings, mainly from strong sales of Windows Vista, caused Microsoft shares to surge as much as 12 percent after hours, reaching a six-year high.
snippet: Better-than-expected earnings, mainly from strong sales of Windows Vista, caused Microsoft shares to surge as much as 12 percent after hours, reaching a six-year high.
lead_paragraph: It turns out someone does like Windows Vista, along with Office and the other stuff Microsoft sells. Indeed, the company sold $1.1 billion more of that stuff in the second quarter than analysts expected. The company’s profits rose by 23 percent.
